metadata.title: Heat Budget Accumulating Day File
metadata.description:
This direct-access disk file contains daily sets of fields of the heat budget parameter generated by the heat budget Product Component. The file accumulates daily sets of data such that it will always contain data for the most recent 37 days. Each daily set of data contains polar stereo and 2.5 X 2.5 degree arrays of day and night longwave radiation and absorbed solar radiation. These are also polar stereo arrays of available solar energy. The file is made up of logical records in two lengths, 31,250 and 20,736 bytes. The longer record occupies 5 blocks and the shorter record 4 blocks.

  The Office of Satellite Data Processing and Distribution (OSDPC) keeps this data for a month, then sends it to the National Climatic Data Center (NCDC) for archiving.  For current data, contact John Sapper at OSDPC,  telephone 301-457-0914 ext.148, e-mail: john.sapper@noaa.gov.  For archived data contact Thomas Ross at NCDC, telephone 828-271-4499, e-mail: tom.ross@noaa.gov.

metadata.title: Heat Budget Monthly Archive Tape (EDIS)
metadata.description:
The heat budget monthly archive tape contains daily sets of heat budget data fields for a calendar month. A daily set consists of both polar stereo and 2.5 X 2.5 degree gridded arrays of Nighttime Longwave Radiation, Daytime Longwave
Radiation, and Absorbed Solar Energy.  Polar stereo arrays of Available Solar Energy are also included.

  The archive tape is a 9-track, 1600 bpi, unlabeled, odd-parity, binary tape produced on an IBM 360/195 computer. Each daily set of arrays is a logical record of 31254 8-bit bytes blocked into 4000 byte physical records with record format VS (variable length records spanning block boundaries).

  The Office of Satellite Data Processing and Distribution (OSDPC) keeps this data for a month, then sends it to the National Climatic Data Center (NCDC) for archiving.  For current data, contact John Sapper at OSDPC,  telephone 301-457-0914 ext.148, e-mail: john.sapper@noaa.gov.  For archived data contact Thomas Ross at NCDC, telephone 828-271-4499, e-mail: tom.ross@noaa.gov.

metadata.title: Independent SST Monthly Storage File
metadata.description:
This file is the reservoir for independent SST observations. From this file they are written each day to the current-day observation file and to a monthly archive tape. The file is a string of logical records, each 6 words long, arranged in physical records of 13008 bytes. Each logical record is the length of one independent SST observation. New observations are entered serially as they arrive, into the next available record on the file. The file is long enough for approximately 40 days worth of data. No sorting or other operations are done before writing to the file.

  The first 2 records of the file are reserved for a directory. Observations are added to the file by checking the directory to determine the next available record number. When the file becomes full, it is recycled, beginning with the first record (#3) available for observation storage.

  The Office of Satellite Data Processing and Distribution (OSDPC) keeps this data for a month, then sends it to the National Climatic Data Center (NCDC) for archiving.  For current data, contact John Sapper at OSDPC,  telephone 301-457-0914 ext.148, e-mail: john.sapper@noaa.gov.  For archived data contact Thomas Ross at NCDC, telephone 828-271-4499, e-mail: tom.ross@noaa.gov.

metadata.title: Workshop on the Potential Effects of Climate Change on Alaska Native Subsistence Resources, Communities, and Cultures

creators.name: Marine Mammal Commission on Native Affairs

metadata.description:
The objectives of this workshop are to (1) identify the potential effects and concerns of Alaska  Native regarding the potential effects of climate change on physical environments and wild living resources of particular importance to the subsistence economies and cultures of Alaska Natives; (2) determine the critical unknowns and the research or monitoring programs required to resolve critical unknowns concerning the possible long-term effects of climate change on environments and wild living resources of particular relevance to the subsistence and cultures of Alaska Natives and (3) initiate contingency planning  necessary to be prepared to minimize or mitigate the impacts of climate change on Alaska Native communities that depend upon fish and wildlife resources for subsistence.  The workshop will be organized by the steering committee established by the Marine Mammal Commission.  

An NPMR project

metadata.title: Monthly Mean SST Accumulation File
metadata.description:
This file provides storage for a global 2.5 degree resolution accumulation of SST information leading to a monthly determination of mean SST and standard deviation within each grid box. Boxes are bordered by meridians and parallels which are multiples of 2.5 degrees in latitude and longitude, so that 4 boxes may be combined to produce boxes centered on intersections of meridians and parallels which are multiples of 5 degrees in latitude and longitude.

Three quantities are stored for each grid box and are operated twice weekly with newly arrived observations. These are 1) the number of observations occurring in the box, 2) the sum of the measured temperatures, and 3) the sum of these temperatures. From these, a mean temperature and standard deviation are derived for each box at the end of each month.

  There are 144 X 72 = 10,368 boxes covering the globe. Each requires 3 words--N, T, T2-- or 12 bytes of storage. Seven latitudinal rows of 144 boxes will fit on one track so that 10 2/7 tracks are required each month. Four months' data will
be maintained on disk so that a quarterly report can be comprised from the file directly. The fourth month makes provision for lags in processing. One directory record will be needed, and 42 tracks are required in all.

  The Office of Satellite Data Processing and Distribution (OSDPC) keeps this data for a month, then sends it to the National Climatic Data Center (NCDC) for archiving.  For current data, contact John Sapper at OSDPC,  telephone 301-457-0914 ext.148, e-mail: john.sapper@noaa.gov.  For archived data contact Thomas Ross at NCDC, telephone 828-271-4499, e-mail: tom.ross@noaa.gov.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To archive global 2.5 degree resolution accumulation of SST.

metadata.title: New Heat Budget Analysis File
metadata.description:
This file contains the gridded analysis fields required by the Heat Budget Analysis Component. The data values from the heat budget retrievals are accumulated in the file and are accessed by the Heat Budget Product Component in order to produce the final mapped fields of the Heat Budget parameters. Daytime Longwave Radiation; Nighttime Longwave Radiation, and Absorbed Solar Radiation. At any given time, the file contains these data for the three most recent 24-hour periods.

  The Office of Satellite Data Processing and Distribution (OSDPC) keeps this data for a month, then sends it to the National Climatic Data Center (NCDC) for archiving. metadata.title: Old Heat Budget Analysis File
metadata.description:
This direct-access disk contains sets of 2.5 degree and polar stereo arrays for the analysis of the heat budget parameters. The fields on this file are Product Component in order to produce the first mapped fields of the heat
budget parameters. The file is made up of 3 daily sets of logical records of various lengths. Each daily set of records provides for the storage of a subset of 2.5 X 2.5 degrees and polar stereo arrays for each of the 3 heat budget parameters. The three subsets contain arrays of Nighttime Longwave Radiation, Daytime Longwave Radiation, and Absorbed Solar Radiation. Each subset contains arrays for accumulating the sums and population of data values
of a particular heat budget parameter.

  The Office of Satellite Data Processing and Distribution (OSDPC) keeps this data for a month, then sends it to the National Climatic Data Center (NCDC) for archiving. metadata.title: Satellite-Derived Climatological Monthly Mean SST Fields
metadata.description:
This data set is a year-long file of monthly mean satellite-derived temperatures produced via manipulation of the data stored in NSS.PSATAV.SST.MOMEAN. For each month of the year, and for each point of its geographical grid, it contains 1) the month's mean temperature; 2) the standard deviation of a single measure; and 3) the number of observations
entering into the mean. Each of these quantities is stored as a 2-byte integer.

  The geographical grid establishes a global field of boxes at 2.5 degree resolution. Boxes are bordered by meridians and parallels which are multiples of 2.5 degrees latitude/longitude, so that 4 boxes may be combined to produce boxes centered on intersections of meridians and parallels which are multiples of 5 degrees in latitude/longitude.

  New data is added to the file monthly via processing of the accumulated observations stored in SS.PSATAV.SST.MOMEAN. Twelve months' data will be maintained on disk so that a single yearly archive tape can be copied from it for future use in deriving a multi-year satellite based climatology. Seventy-two tracks are therefore required for the data set which will contain 12 X 72 = 864 logical records.

  The Office of Satellite Data Processing and Distribution (OSDPC) keeps this data for a month, then sends it to the National Climatic Data Center (NCDC) for archiving.  For current data, contact John Sapper at OSDPC,  telephone 301-457-0914 ext.148, e-mail: john.sapper@noaa.gov.  For archived data contact Thomas Ross at NCDC, telephone 828-271-4499, e-mail: tom.ross@noaa.gov.

metadata.title: Sitka CoastWatch Graphics
metadata.description: This graphics sector file contains one image of graphics for Sitka in the Gulf of Alaska. This file has no header record. Each logical record in this graphics file corresponds to an image row and each word in a logical record corresponds to an image column: the pixels are one byte in length. The number of data records is the same as the number of image rows and the length of the records is the same as the number of columns. Each of the eight bits in a pixel represents an individual graphics plane. The graphics file is used as input by IMGMAP, which overlays the image it produces with the graphics present in the graphics file. This graphics file can be downloaded to any display work station to display graphics.

metadata.title: SST Matchup Data Base
metadata.description:
This file is a geographically organized data base of satellite SST observation matched with coincident buoy, wx ship, and perhaps XBT data and the SST field data which have been quality controlled. The file generally contains all previous matched observations within the last 30 days. The file contains 5 X 5 degree latitude/longitude blocks which in turn are
subdivided into 1 degree blocks.

The coincident buoy, wx ship and/or XBT data will occupy the first 32 bytes, followed by the field data in the next 32 bytes and the satellite observation which can be of variable size, in which the first 19 halfwords are of fixed format (i.e. contain the core information) and the remainder will have up to a maximum size of 120 bytes. Within the observation no odd full word may be negative except the first full word which must be negative. The access routine COAR2 should be used to reference data in this data set.

The file has overflow records and as such expands and decreases as data are available. The file holds 1 month worth of data. The physical records are one track (13024 bytes) long as are the logical records. The first record is a directory, containing the block directory. Each succeeding record contains a subdirectory followed by the observations.

  The Office of Satellite Data Processing and Distribution (OSDPC) keeps this data for a month, then sends it to the National Climatic Data Center (NCDC) for archiving.  For current data, contact John Sapper at OSDPC,  telephone 301-457-0914 ext.148, e-mail: john.sapper@noaa.gov.  For archived data contact Thomas Ross at NCDC, telephone 828-271-4499, e-mail: tom.ross@noaa.gov.

metadata.title: Target Matchup Data Base
metadata.description:
This file is a reservoir for AVHRR and HIRS/2 target data collocated with SST observation and buoy observation data. The target and SST observation data for selected geographic locations are written from a temporary file by an operational copy program once a day. The temporary file is created by the SST reduction program (MUT) on an orbit by orbit basis. Once a day, coincident buoy data is added to the appropriate target records in the Target Matchup Data Base (TMDB) by a merge program. A tape archive of the data base is made periodically by copying the disk to tape.

The file is a circular file of logical records, each 3150 bytes long, arranged in physical records of 3150 bytes. The first record is a header record containing a data record pointer and the starting and ending times of each directory record. The next 28 records are reserved as directory records. Directory records contain such information as the data record numbers, latitude and longitude, and times for groups of 150 data records. Each succeeding 3150 byte logical record is a data record which is the length of one colocated AVHRR and HIRS/2 target data matched with coincident buoy data and satellite SST observations. Note, the header and data records for the TARGET MATCHUP INITIAL STORAGE FILE (TMISF) have the same length and format as that of the TMDB. The file is large enough to hold 4200 observations.

Observations are added to the file by checking the header to determine the next available record number. When the file becomes full, it is recycled beginning with the first data record (record #30) for observation storage. The appropriate directory record is then updated.


  The Office of Satellite Data Processing and Distribution (OSDPC) keeps this data for a month, then sends it to the National Climatic Data Center (NCDC) for archiving.  For current data, contact John Sapper at OSDPC,  telephone 301-457-0914 ext.148, e-mail: john.sapper@noaa.gov.  For archived data contact Thomas Ross at NCDC, telephone 828-271-4499, e-mail: tom.ross@noaa.gov.

metadata.title: Target Matchup Data Base Archive Tape
metadata.description:
This archive tape contains copies of the Target Matchup Data Base (NSS.PSATAVST.SST.TARMCH) and the SST Matchup Data Base (NSS.PSATAVST.SST.MCHUP). It is produced on the 3rd of each month, archiving data for the previous month. The Target Matchup Data Base contains raw data targets (i.e. AVHRR and HIRS/2 raw data, calibration coefficients, and earth location information) as well as any retrieved SST's for selected geographic positions. If a target position coincides with a fixed buoy location, that buoy SST is appended to the target (targets and buoys are matched within 24 hours). The SST Matchup Data Base is a geographically organized file of satellite SST and buoy SST matchups where the buoy and satellite match within 100 km and 48 hours.

The tape is a 9-track, 1600 bpi, unlabeled, odd-parity, binary tape produced on an IBM 360/195 computer. The tape has three physical files, each ending with a physical end-of-file mark. The first file has only one record (physical) which contains information about the data on the tape and serves as a header file. The second file has 4232 physical records of 3150 bytes each which contains the Target Matchup Data Base records. The third file has 900 physical records of 13024 bytes each which contain the SST Matchup Data Base records. The format for both data base files are identical to the disk file formats of these data bases.

  The Office of Satellite Data Processing and Distribution (OSDPC) keeps this data for a month, then sends it to the National Climatic Data Center (NCDC) for archiving.  For current data, contact John Sapper at OSDPC,  telephone 301-457-0914 ext.148, e-mail: john.sapper@noaa.gov.  For archived data contact Thomas Ross at NCDC, telephone 828-271-4499, e-mail: tom.ross@noaa.gov.

metadata.title: Harbor seal biological sampling: expanding the scope of the subsistence archival project.
metadata.description:
This project will expand the scope of the Alaska Native Harbor Seal Commission's (ANHSC) present biological sampling efforts to include subsistence hunters in communities west of Prince William Sound. The Commission is a tribal consortium
concerned with self-management of the harbor seal (Phoca vitulina) as a subsistence resource. The ANHSC already conducts a biological sampling program in nine communities and participates in the harvest data assessment program with the
Alaska Department of Fish and Game Subsistence Division. We plan to expand this effort to nine more communities in western Alaska and the Aleutian Islands. Local technicians are selected and trained by the Commission's staff to perform basic necropsies on seals taken by subsistence hunters. Samples from these seals are sent to the University of Alaska Museum (UAM) for distribution to ongoing investigations and for archiving in the permanent collections.  Tissue samples will be archived in the Alaska Frozen Tissue Collection (AFTC) which has become the primary regional archive for frozen zoological samples and a major contributor to environmental studies of the North Pacific and Arctic oceans. It is now the world's third largest frozen tissue collection for wild mammals (Hafner et al. 1997). The increasingly powerful tools of molecular biology and biochemistry and the need to monitor perturbation of the environment are accelerating both collection growth and usage. In addition to supporting expanded
monitoring and sampling by the ANHSC, this project supports additional student help at UAM to process the increased number of samples. This project will increase the scope of sampling from a protected and potentially threatened high-trophic-level subsistence resource, and increase the scope of Native involvement in the study and management of marine resources.  This project also includes; Gordon Jarrell, University of Alaska Fairbanks, P.O. Box 757220, Fairbanks, Alaska  99775-7220, fnghj@uaf.edu

Monica Riedel,  Alaska Native Harbor Seal Commission, P.O. Box 2229, Cordova, AK 99574, Phone:(907) 424-5882, FAX: (907) 424-5883, aksealmr@ptialaska.net

metadata.title: Visible Cloud Threshold Table
metadata.description:
The data set consists of bidirectional reflectance values derived from radiance measurements from one of the visible channels of AVHRR and channel 20 of the HIRS/2 instrument for a cloud-free atmosphere over ocean. They are
stored in the data set as functions of the solar zenith angle, satellite zenith angle, and the relative azimuth angle.

The data set consists of 19 logical records, each being equal to 3888 bytes. The first record of the file is a directory which identifies the satellite ID (1 to N), the date of creation, and the date of the most recent modification. The next two records contain the 'test values' of bidirectional reflectance for a cloud-free atmosphere (i.e. the threshold values) for the visible channel of the AVHRR and channel 20 of the HIRS/2 instrument, respectively. Records 4-19 contain the best threshold values of the reflectance for the two instruments for up to 8 satellites. The AVHRR thresholds are in the first record of each pair, the HIRS/2 in the second. The satellite is defined in the directory record.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To archive bidirectional reflectance data.

metadata.title: AVHRR GAC, LAC and HRPT Level 1b Data Set
metadata.description:
The Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) sensor is carried on NOAA's Polar Orbiting Environmental Satellites (POES) starting with TIROS-N in 1978. Onboard the TIROS-N, NOAA-6, 8 and 10 POES Satellites, the AVHRR Sensor measures in 4 spectral bands, while those on the NOAA-7, 9, 11, 12, 14, and 15 POES Satellites are measured in 5. The primary objective of the AVHRR instrument is to provide cloud top and sea surface temperatures through passively measured visible, near infrared and thermal infrared spectral radiation bands.

  NOAA Polar Orbiting Environmental Satellites obtain global imagery daily which are transmitted to the Command and Data Acquisition (CDA) stations at Wallops Island, Virginia, and Fairbanks, Alaska. The CDA stations relay the data to the National Environmental Satellite, Data and Information Service (NESDIS), located in Suitland, Maryland, for processing and distribution to forecasting centers of the U.S. and other nations.

  GAC (Global Area Coverage) data is produced from AVHRR data aboard NOAA operational polar orbiting satellites. The GAC data are produced on-board the satellite by sampling the AVHRR 1 km data to 4 km resolution by averaging
along-scan groups of four samples out of five and skipping every third scan.  The data includes all 5 channels at 10 bit precision, with time tags, Earth location, and calibration information.

  The LAC Level 1B data are 1 km resolution data that are recorded on-board the satellite and dumped at the CDA stations, at some later time.

  The HRPT Level 1B data are 1 km direct readout data obtained as the satellite passes over CDA Stations. Hardcopy imagery from HRPT data are also available. Each dataset is generally 10-12 minutes in duration, which requires 3 frames
per channel.

metadata.title: DMSP SSM/I Environmental Data Records
metadata.description:
The Defense Meteorological Satellite Program (DMSP) is a Department of Defense program which is responsible for designing, building, launching and operating polar orbiting meteorological satellites. The satellites can broadcast visual,
infrared and microwave imagery directly to transportable tactical sites around the world. The data is also stored for transmission to the Navy's Fleet Numerical Meteorology and Oceanography Center (FNMOC) and to the Air Force
Global Weather Central (AFGWC).
  
  Each of the DMSP satellites flies in a sun-synchronous, near-polar orbit. For a satellite in sun synchronous orbit, the ascending equatorial crossing time remains relatively constant with respect to the local time throughout the lifetime of the satellite.
  
  The SSM/I is a seven channel, four frequency, linearly-polarized passive microwave radiometric system which measures atmospheric, ocean and terrain microwave brightness temperatures at 19.35, 22.235, 37.0 and 85.5 GHz. SSM/I's
output voltages are transmitted to the FNMOC in Monterey, California, where they are converted to sensor counts. FNMOC then converts the sensor counts into antenna temperatures (Temperature Data Records - TDR), brightness temperatures (Sensor Data Records - SDR) and derived geophysical parameters (Environmental Data Records -EDR). SSM/I TDRs are sent to NOAA-SAA for their on-line database. The SSM/I rotates continuously about an axis parallel to the local spacecraft vertical at 31.6 rpm and measures the upwelling scene brightness temperatures over an angular sector of 102.4 degrees about the subsatellite track. This results in a swath width of approximately 1400 km.

  The EDR data are derived from TDRs and SDRs, and measure various parameters over the ocean, ice and land surfaces. There are five oceanic parameters: surface wind speed, cloud water content, water vapor content, rainfall intensity and liquid water content. There are four ice parameters: ice concentration, ice age, ice edge and cloud water content over ice. There are eight land parameters: rain intensity, liquid water content, surface moisture, cloud water content, snow water content, surface character, surface temperature and cloud amount. Not all parameters are simultaneously possible.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To collect atmospheric, ocean and terrain microwave brightness temperatures and environmental data.

metadata.title: DMSP SSM/I Temperature Data Records
metadata.description:
The Defense Meteorological Satellite Program (DMSP) is a Department of Defense program which is responsible for designing, building, launching and operating polar orbiting meteorological satellites. The satellites can broadcast visual,
infrared and microwave imagery directly to transportable tactical sites around the world. The data is also stored for transmission to the Navy's Fleet Numerical Meteorology and Oceanography Center (FNMOC) and to the Air Force
Global Weather Central (AFGWC).
 
  Each of the DMSP satellites flies in a sun-synchronous, near-polar orbit. For a satellite in sun synchronous orbit, the ascending equatorial crossing time remains relatively constant with respect to the local time throughout the lifetime of the satellite.
 
  The SSM/I is a seven-channel, four-frequency, linearly-polarized, passive microwave radiometric system.  The SSM/I receives both horizontally and vertically linearly polarized radiation at 19.3, 37.0 and 85.5 GHz and vertical only at 22.2 GHz.  SSM/I's output voltages are transmitted to the Navy's Fleet Numerical Meteorology and Oceanography Center (FNMOC) in Monterey, CA, where they are converted to sensor counts.  FNMOC then converts the sensor counts into antenna temperatures (TDR), brightness temperatures (SDR) and derived geophysical parameters (EDR).  SSM/I TDR data are sent to NOAA-SAA for their on-line database.  

  The SSM/I rotates continuously about an axis parallel to the local spacecraft vertical at 31.6 rpm and measures the upwelling scene brightness temperatures over an angular sector of 102.4 degrees about the subsatellite track.  The results in a swath width of approximately 1400 km.

  The SSM/I TDR data set is produced by the NOAA/National Environmental Satellite Data and Information Service (NESDIS).  NESDIS' Satellite Active Archive (SAA) ingests the data from NESDIS (as of 4/1/97) on an orbit-by-orbit basis and assembles the data into an approximate one day file set.  The data is stored as SSM/I antenna temperatures for each of seven instrument channels.  The earth location (latitude and longitude) values are assigned for every data point. 
Hot and cold calibration values are also stored within the file.

  The data files can be converted to brightness temperatures by applying a conversion utility.  Each file set is approximately 80 Mbytes (uncompressed).  This data set is archived on-line and is available for distribution on a variety of magnetic media:  9 track 6250 bpi round tapes, 3480 cartridges, 4mm and 8mm tapes.  Similar data sets are available for the SSM/I
instrument aboard the F11 and F12 DMSP satellites.

metadata.description:
The Defense Meteorological Satellite Program (DMSP) is a Department of Defense program which is responsible for designing, building, launching and operating polar orbiting meteorological satellites. The satellites can broadcast visual,
infrared and microwave imagery directly to transportable tactical sites around the world. The data is also stored for transmission to the Navy's Fleet Numerical Meteorology and Oceanography Center (FNMOC) and to the Air Force
Global Weather Central (AFGWC).
 
  Each of the DMSP satellites flies in a sun-synchronous, near-polar orbit. For a satellite in sun synchronous orbit, the ascending equatorial crossing time remains relatively constant with respect to the local time throughout the lifetime of the satellite.
 
  The SSM/T1 consists of seven microwave channels with atmospheric sensitivity in the oxygen absorption band, at frequencies ranging from 50.5 to 59.4 GHz, with one channel acting as a surface window channel. The SSM/T1completes one scan of seven earth view measurements and two calibration measurements every 32 seconds. The total swath width for the SSM/T1 is approximately 1600 km.

metadata.title: DMSP SSM/T2 NESDIS Level 1B
metadata.description:
The Defense Meteorological Satellite Program (DMSP) is a Department of Defense program which is responsible for designing, building, launching and operating polar orbiting meteorological satellites. The satellites can broadcast visual, infrared and microwave imagery directly to transportable tactical sites around the world. The data is also stored for transmission to the Navy's Fleet Numerical Meteorology and Oceanography Center (FNMOC) and to the Air Force Global Weather Central (AFGWC).

  Each of the DMSP satellites flies in a sun-synchronous, near-polar orbit. For a satellite in sun synchronous orbit, the ascending equatorial crossing time remains relatively constant with respect to the local time throughout the lifetime of the satellite.
 
  The SSM/T2 is the first operational microwave water vapor sounder to be placed in orbit. It is a scanning, five channel, passive and total power microwave radiometer system. The SSM/T2 consists of five channels: three water vapor channels centered around the 183.31 GHz water vapor line, a 91 GHz channel, and a 150 GHz channel. The SSM/T2 observation rate is 7.5 scans per minute. There are 28 observations (beam positions) per scan for each of the five channels, with each observation having a spatial resolution of approximately 48 km. All five channels have coincident centers. The total swath width for the SSM/T2 is approximately 1400 km.

metadata.title: TOVS MSU, SSU and HIRS/2 Level 1b Data Set
metadata.description:
The TIROS Operational Vertical Sounder (TOVS) system consists of three separate instruments: High Resolution Infrared Radiation Sounder Version 2 (HIRS/2), Microwave Sounding Unit (MSU) and Stratospheric Sounding Unit (SSU). Each instrument has different characteristics, resolutions, scan properties, etc. which are described below. This system is onboard the NOAA 6 through NOAA 14 and TIROS-N satellites. 

  The HIRS/2 instrument is a step-scanned multi-channel spectrometer with 20 channels primarily in the infrared region of the spectrum including both longwave (15 micron) and shortwave (4.3 micron), plus one channel in the visible (.69 micron) region. Resolution of 17 km at nadir, but at the end of a scan, resolution is 58 km cross-track by 30 km along-track with variable underlap between steps and scans. The data include all 20 channels at 13 bit precision with time tags, Earth location and calibration information. 

  The SSU is a step-scanned infrared spectrometer with 3 channels in the 15 micron C02 band. The 3 SSU channels have the same frequency but different cell pressures. Resolution of 147 km at subpoint with an underlap between adjacent scan lines of approximately 62 km at nadir. The data include all 3 channels at 12 bit precision, with time tags, Earth location and calibration information. 

  The MSU instrument is a passive scanning microwave spectrometer with four channels in the 5.5 micron oxygen region. The 124 km resolution at the subpoint creates an underlap of 115 km between adjacent scan lines. Data include all 4 channels at 12 bit precision with time tags, Earth location and calibration information.

metadata.title: Sea-Air-Land Modeling and Observing Network (SALMON) Project
metadata.description:
This project is a program at the University of Alaska that fosters the implementation and operation of ocean-observing systems in the Northern Gulf of Alaska.  The SALMON Project, in cooperation with other institutes, is providing continuous real-time or near real-time observations of ocean circulation and ecosystems and linking these with models to provide ocean forecasts in much the same way that weather forecasts are made.

  Provided information includes: mesoscale survey, SeaWiFS images, Coastal Gulf of Alaska (CGOA) numerical modeling, real-time sea surface temperatures, CODAR (real-time mapping of surface currents) in Alaska, the Gulf of Alaska 4 (GAK4) mooring, and bathymetric maps.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To bring together managers, industry partners, researchers, educators and others in a collaborative efforts to establish an ocean observatory in the Northern Gulf of Alaska, from Kayak Island in the east to the Shumagin Islands west of Kodiak, including Price William Sound and Cook Inlet and the outer coast of Kodiak.  These observations and forecasts will enhance and protect the livelihoods of those who use this productive water body and depend on its ecosystem for food, livelihood, recreation, and transportation.

metadata.title: Coastal Gulf of Alaska Circulation Model (3-km grid)
metadata.description:
The SALMON Project is currently utilizing the Arctic Region Supercomputing Center (ARSC) to run numerical simulations of the circulation of the coastal Gulf of Alaska. The model in use is called the Regional Ocean Modeling System (ROMS), developed jointly by researchers at the University of California at Los Angeles and Rutgers University. It is run at a resolution of three kilometers and aligned in a nested grid configuration with Al Hermann's North East Pacific (NEP) domain. Open boundary conditions are provided by the NEP model and COADS monthly mean wind fields are used for the surface forcing. Tidal forcings are computed from Mike Foreman's northeast Pacific Ocean high-resolution assimilating tide model and are applied along the open boundaries of the model domain. Fresh water inputs consist of a continuous line source of monthly mean values computed by Tom Royer's hydrologic model. The latest ROMS model run simulated three idealized years of circulation in the northern Gulf of Alaska. 

  There are thirty vertical levels using a nonlinear stretching to improve the surface resolution in deep water. The vertical mixing scheme is KPP with both surface and bottom boundary layers. The open boundary conditions are Flather/Chapman for the barotropic fields; these provide the tidal elevation and currents added to the barotropic fields from the NEP model. The baroclinic fields have a modified radiation condition where the direction of the phase velocity determines the strength of the nudging to the NEP fields. There is also a ten-point wide nudging band on temperature and salinity along the open boundaries, again using the NEP fields.

  Our future plans include coupled ecosystem models and the use of NCEP daily winds, making sure that all the nested models use common forcing fields. We will be running for specific years, such as 2000 and 2001.


  A Sea-Air-Land Modeling and Observing Network (SALMON) Project.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To simulate the coastal Gulf of Alaska circulation.

metadata.title: CODAR Surface Current Mapping in Alaska
metadata.description:
The Salmon Project is in the process of deploying new High Frequency (HF) Radar instrumentation which will provide unprecedented coverage of sea surface currents in Alaskan waters. These surface current mappers (SCMs) are instruments manufactured by CODAR (Coastal Ocean Dynamic Applications Radar) Ocean Sensors in Los Altos, California. They will be phased into operation through the spring and summer of 2004 at remote sites in Prince William Sound and the Northern Gulf of Alaska. These prototype power and telemetry systems are currently in their final testing phase at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. The funding for these systems is being provided by grants awarded by The National Aeronautical and Space Administration (NASA) and The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).

  A Sea-Air-Land Modeling and Observing Network (SALMON) Project.
metadata.notes:

metadata.title: Alaskan Bathymetric Maps
metadata.description:
The University of Alaska's Institute of Marine Science is in possession of a proprietary data set compiled by Scientific Fishery Systems Inc. This bathymetric data set consists of NODC soundings point data which has been translated to NAD83 where necessary. The data is of very high resolution near some coastal areas and very coarse in others, in the deeper parts of the continental shelf and open ocean, there is hardly any coverage at all. A map individual data points in this data set is shown below. For more information on this data set see the SciFish website http://www.scifish.com/newWeb/productIndiv.py?2.

  In order to get a high resolution bathymetric data set which was capable of supplying a numerical model with adequate coverage on a 3 km grid the SALMON Project group at UAF decided to combine a number of data sets. For the deep ocean, we decided to use ETOPO5 a global data set of land and sea elevations on a 5 minute latitude/longitude grid. For the coastal areas the SciFish data set was used and for the land the Smith and Sandwell 30 second gridded data was used. Routines written in the feely available software package called the Generic Mapping Tools (GMT) were used to combine these three data sets, grid them all onto a 30 second latitude/longitude grid and produce maps.

  A Sea-Air-Land Modeling and Observing Network (SALMON) Project.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To show the coverage available in the coastal areas of Alaska.

metadata.title: SciFish Bathymetric Data
metadata.description: SciFish has bathymetry data for all Alaska regions and for many parts of the U.S. West Coast.  The data can be used directly with SciFish software or converted into the file format of user's choosing.  Data sources include: transformed coastline points that agree closely with the best available nautical charts and that have been densified to match the highest resolution of the point data; NODC soundings point data, translated to NAD83 where necessary, and trimmed to agree with the coastline; NODC tracking point data, edited to remove unreliable tracklines, translated to NAD83 where necessary, and trimmed to agree with the coastline; and hand-entered depth soundings from NOAA Nautical charts.  The data will be delivered as a X, Y, Z (lon., lat., depth) ASCII file suitable for ingestion into any database or spatial analysis program on CD-ROM.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: Comprehensive soundings data for Alaska and West Coast U.S..

metadata.title: Marine Mammal & Bird Stranding

creators.name: Alaska Sea Otter & Steller Sea Lion Commission

metadata.description:
Marine mammals are vital to the subsistence lifestyle and economy of coastal Alaska Natives. In 1988, six coastal Alaska Native regions formed the Alaska Sea Otter Commission to restore Alaska Native governance over the northern sea otter. In November 1998, the Commission expanded its role as a statewide organization to advocate on behalf of Steller sea lion and Alaska Native relationships. The organization officially expanded to The Alaska Sea Otter& Steller Sea Lion Commission (TASSC). In 1992, the Commission developed regional management plans for each of its six regions. Recognized within these plans is a need for local participation in research and management. Research includes building regional capacity by training local residents on the methods of biological sampling of the northern sea otter. In 1995, the Commission received funding to implement a biological training program. Over 55 local people from within the six coastal regions received training. To date, 185 biological samples from subsistence harvested sea otters were collected for research. This project expands the biological sampling program to train local people on marine mammal and bird stranding protocols.

This project also includes;

Kimberly Williams 
Alaska Sea Otter & Steller Sea Lion Commission

Anchorage, Alaska  99503-6199

metadata.title: SciFish Acoustic Data Library
metadata.description: Acoustic Data Library (ADL) for the broadband split-beam fish tracker.  Acoustic data has been collected from over 15 locations worldwide. With over 100 weeks of trials in oceans, lakes, rivers, and pools SciFish 2000 has successfully collected data for over 20 different species including Pacific herring, Lake sturgeon, paddlefish, Chinook and Sockeye salmon, Alaskan walleye pollock, jellyfish, krill, Pacific halibut, alewife, smelt, Pacific Cod, and Pacific Ocean Perch. The ADL consists of documentation, data and databases that serves as a repository for broadband acoustic data, its associated parameters, and collection conditions.

metadata.title: Creating a Bering Sea Council of Elders for Stewardship in the Bering Sea
metadata.description:
Indigenous peoples, including the Aleut, Inupiat, Ittelman, Koryak, Siberian Yupik, and Alaska Yupik, have coexisted with the Bering Sea for over eight thousand years, living successfully by their understanding of the winds, tides, currents, climate, and sea ice to harvest fish and wildlife. Such traditional knowledge and wisdom long ago taught Alaska Natives that in order to thrive they must assume an active stewardship role with the land, the sea, and all its creatures. Through time, the Bering Sea has come to mean everything to coastal peoples: it is the spiritual, cultural, physical, and economic centerpoint of their lives. In the most profound sense, this sea and the people who live along its coast have become one.  As outside organizations identify research priorities and management decisions are being made, it is critical that Bering Sea coastal people, whose lives remain wholly dependent on an abundant and diverse marine ecosystem, have an active role in understanding the problems and policies affecting them, and to
decided what steps they need to take. However, because the coastal residents are organized into community, sub-regional, and regional groups, there is no forum for collective decisions on an ecosystem-wide basis. The Council of Elders' leadership is
necessary to unify and prioritize the research goals of the region's Native peoples.

An NPMR project
metadata.notes:
Purpose: A proposal for NPMR to establish A Bering Sea Council of Elders for stewardship in the Bering Sea.

metadata.title: Chemical and Isotopic Tracers from the Arctic Ocean
metadata.description:
These data are water column and sediment data tabulated in Microsoft Excel spreadsheets. They were largely collected in the Bering and Chukchi Seas, with some coverage for the Beaufort and East Siberian Seas, and with limited coverage for other portions of the Arctic Ocean. Data include that collected on Alpha Helix cruises 139, 165, 166, 174, 189, 190, 214, and 224 between 1990 and 1999. Other data were obtained from cruises of the RV OKEAN (1993), USCGC Polar Star (1993), Mendeleev (1993), USCGC Polar Sea (2000), U.S. Canada Arctic Ocean Section (1994), and Polarstern (1993).

  Water column data include coverage from some to most stations on these cruises, and include bottle salinity, temperature, sigma-t, oxygen-18/16 ratios, phosphate, ammonia, silicate, nitrate, dissolved oxygen, iodine-129 concentrations, and chlorophyll a. Sediment data include plutonium and neptunium concentrations, including isotope data.

  Biological data include radionuclide burdens in marine mammal tissues donated by subsistence hunters on the North Slope of Alaska and in the Resolute region of Canada.

  The readme files include reference to published use of these data, as well as additional information on interpreting data columns and spreadsheet construction. Additional biological and chemical data are being prepared for distribution at this site, and will be available in the near future.


  Data Citation: Cooper, L.W. 2001. Chemical and isotopic tracers from the Arctic Ocean. Boulder, CO: National Snow and Ice Data Center. Digital media.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To collect chemical and isotopic tracers in the subpolar region.

metadata.title: AFSC Marine Salmon Interactions Monitoring Data Sets: Auke Creek
metadata.description: The Auke Lake system has natural populations of pink, chum, sockeye and coho salmon, and supports populations of Dolly Varden, and cutthroat and steelhead trout.  Chinook salmon have returned to Auke Creek since 1986 as a result of off-site releases of juveniles from other hatcheries. The National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS), and its predecessor agency, the U.S. Bureau of Commercial Fisheries, began salmon research at Auke Creek in 1961. Several fish counting weirs were installed in Auke Creek to capture salmon adults during the early 1960s. In 1965, a permanent, low-height weir was constructed and was used until 1980, when a modern, two-way weir was built. Weir counts of sockeye salmon adults at Auke Creek began in 1963; other species were included after 1966. Sockeye smolts were counted in some years between 1963 and 1980, and other downstream migrants were counted after 1969.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To document  the species composition, abundance, and timing of potential prey organisms as food for pink and chum salmon fry first entering nearshore marine waters.  This early marine residency of salmon fry is crucial in determining survival to adult and year-class strength.

metadata.title: AFSC Marine Salmon Interactions Monitoring Data Sets: Little Port Walter - 2003 Returning Adult Chinook Salmon
metadata.description: From June to August, 2003, 1824 returning adult chinook salmon were recovered at the research hatchery at LPW.  Of this total, 1691 fish were recovered with coded-wire tags (CWTs): 1686 that had been released from LPW and 5 strays from other facilities.  The returning LPW chinook salmon were composed of two stocks: Chickamin River stock and Unuk River stock.  Both of these stocks, originating from the Behm Canal area of southern Southeast Alaska have been cultured at LPW for seven generations.  Unuk River stock comprised 76.5% (1289 fish) of the returning fish, whereas Chickamin River stock comprised 23.5% (397 fish).  Of the total returning LPW chinook, 58.0% were males (978 fish), 40.6% were females (685 fish), and 1.4% were of undetermined sex (23 fish).  For both the Chickamin River stock and the Unuk River stock, 5 year old fish dominated the return.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To document  the species composition, abundance, and timing of potential prey organisms as food for pink and chum salmon fry first entering nearshore marine waters.  This early marine residency of salmon fry is crucial in determining survival to adult and year-class strength.

metadata.description: On May 19, 2003, 193,594 chinook salmon smolts (2001 brood year) were released with CWTs from LPW.  Of this total, 28,639 (14.8%) were Unuk River stock, and 164,955 (85.2%) were Chickamin River stock.  Unuk River stock were released at a mean weight of 21.5 g, and the Chickamin River stock were released at a mean weight of 19.4 g.  The fish had been tagged with CWTs in October, 2002.

metadata.title: AFSC Marine Salmon Interactions Monitoring Data Sets: Auke Bay - Plankton Abundance
metadata.description: Plankton have been sampled yearly in Auke Bay since the 1970s as an index of environmental conditions for salmon fry.  The Auke Bay Monitor station (ABM) is sampled weekly from March or April until fry have left the nearshore habitat in June, then monthly, until October each year.  Three replicate samples of the upper water column are collected with a 20-m vertical tow using a 0.5 m diameter, 243 Fm mesh Norpac net.  Settled volumes are measured immediately in the laboratory, then samples are preserved for detailed microscopic analysis of species, stage and size composition and enumeration.  A long-term database is maintained for interannual comparisons.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To index environmental conditions for salmon fry.

Status: In Progress

metadata.title: AFSC Marine Salmon Interactions Monitoring Data Sets: Auke Bay - Water Temperature and Salinity
metadata.description: A 20-m temperature-salinity profile is measured with a CTD each time plankton samples are collected.  The hydrographic structure of the surface water column used by juvenile salmon is thus monitored from its spring structure of a freshwater lens over a colder, more saline (denser) layer to a summer mixed structure throughout the period that juvenile salmon use the nearshore and strait habitats.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To monitor marine salmon interactions.

metadata.title: AFSC Coded-Wire Tags Data Sets
metadata.description: The Coded-Wire Tag (CWT) is a small piece of magnetized stainless steel wire with a code etched on the surface. A standard-sized CWT is 1.1 mm long x 0.25 mm diameter and is generally used on juvenile salmon larger than 2 g in weight. For smaller salmon averaging as little as 0.2 g, tags half this length can be used (lower picture).  Since 1968, 82 Federal, State, Indian, and private agencies in Alaska, Washington, Oregon, Idaho, California, and British Columbia have released over 600 million salmon with CWTs. Currently, over 45 million young salmon are marked with CWTs and released to migrate into the Pacific Ocean every year.  Information on the release, sample, and recovery of all CWT salmonids throughout the Pacific region is available in an on-line coastwide database, the
metadata.notes:
Purpose: Since the late 1960's, CWTs have been the primary means for marking Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) for stock assessment, harvest management, and enhancement evaluation.

metadata.title: Surface Meteorology Time Series Data of the Gulf of Alaska and Bering Sea by PMEL FOCI Program  (PMEL EPIC)
metadata.description:
This one-dimensional surface meteorology data set indexed by time, includes wind, air temperature, relative humidity, shortwave rediation, barometric pressure, etc. from the Gulf of Alaska and Bering Sea.  There are 59 files available for plotting and download.  Depth range was from -73.099 to 1322 meters deep.  Data were collected by the PMEL scientists with the FOCI Program.  Data have been formatted for Web by NOAA/PMEL/EPIC and are available on-line through the PMEL EPIC program.  Access to download data from individual casts in either ASCII or netCDF format is included.  A variety of plots of properties versus depth and property vs. property plots can be generated on the fly and displayed to your screen.

  [PMEL - Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory (http://www.pmel.noaa.gov/), FOCI - Fisheries-Oceanography Coordinated Investigations (http://www.pmel.noaa.gov/foci/home.html)]
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To support oceanographic time series.

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: Unknown

Access constraints: None

metadata.title: Subsurface Mooring Data from Akutan Pass, Aleutian Islands: Station Akutan Pass 1
metadata.description: Subsurface mooring data from Akutan Pass, Aleutian Islands: Station Akutan Pass 1.  Data were collected from 1994 through 2004.  Sampled months varied through the years but were usually during April, May, and October.  Salinity, temperature, and velocity data were collected at various depths throughout the years using instruments such as ADCP, MicroCAT, and SBE-39.  83m was the maximum bottom depth.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To collect physical oceanographic properties at and near the mooring locations.

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: Unknown

Sampled months varied through the years but were usually during May.  Temperature, UV vector, and velocity data were collected at various depths throughout the years using instruments such as ADCP, RCM-9, and RCM-11.  5100m was the maximum bottom depth.
metadata.notes:

metadata.title: No. 152 - Age, sex and size of Yukon River salmon catch and escapement,  1984.  By Lawrence S. Buklis and Gregory T. Ruggerone.  July  985  43 pp.
metadata.description: Included (but are not limited to): (1)  Salmon abundance, catch and escapement studies  (2) annual smolt studies  (3) tagging studies  (4) annual federal aid reports  (5) special short-term or interim reports on equipment or methodologies, stock identification, management, life history, etc and (6) some annual  U.S./ Canada reports.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: Publications in this series are usually technically oriented and additionally have the following characteristics:  (1)  timely reporting of mostly final data, although minor future adjustments are acceptable (2) content usually annual iterative or interim in nature (3) data in a basic form (but not raw data) may be archived

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: Annually

Access constraints: Request for one or two pages of data and/or short reports can usually be accommodated.

Use constraints: Republications of materials in this report series may be authorized by the department

metadata.title: Subsurface Mooring Data from the Bering Sea: Station Inner Front 9
metadata.description: Subsurface mooring data from the Bering Sea: Station Inner Front 9.  Data were collected from 1994 through 2004.  Sampled months varied through the years but were usually during April and June.  Salinity, temperature, and UV vector data were collected at various depths throughout the years using instruments such as MTR, RCM-4, and RCM-7.  50m was the maximum bottom depth.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To collect physical oceanographic properties at and near the mooring locations.

metadata.title: 92-30 Sonar  Enumeration of Pacific Salmon Escapement Into the Nushagak River, 1991.  James D. Woolington and James D. Miller.   56 pp.
metadata.description: Includes (but are not limited to:) (1) Alaska Board of Fisheries and Fishery Management council reports (2) Season summaries (3) White papers (4) management plans (5) annual test fish results (6) legislative reports (7) forecast (8) area management reports (9) annual shellfish surveys (10) some annual U.S./Canada;  and since the 1993, the following studies have been published in this series:  (11) Salmon abundance, catch and escapements studies (12) annual smolt reports (13) tagging studies and (14) special short-term or interim reports on equipment or methodologies, stock identification, management, life history, etc..
metadata.notes:
Purpose: This series is primarily informational, serving to: (1) promote intradepartmental exchange of information and (2) meet ad hoc reporting functions of the department to other agencies, governmental and regulatory bodies, the fishing industry and the public.  Reports in this series may achieve original observations (raw data) or contain preliminary or incomplete data.  These reports do not receive full editorial and peer review.  Reports may be highly individualized.

Maintenance frequency: Annually

metadata.title: A Dual-Doppler Radar Study of Longitudinal-Mode Snowbands. Part I: A Three-Dimensional Kinematic Structure of Meso--Scale Connective Cloud Systems within a Longitudinal-Mode Snowband
metadata.description:
Observations of snowstorms were carried out around Ishikari Bay, Hokkaido,
     Japan, from December 1991 to February 1992. On 15 January 1992, a
     longitudinal-mode snowband was observed by a dual-Doppler radar system. The
     snowband was composed of meso--scale (20 km) connective cloud
     systems. The three-dimensional kinematic structures and organization processes
     of the meso--scale systems were studied in detail.

       Strong band-parallel winds appeared in the upper-north rear of the
     meso--scale systems. Since their speed was faster than that of the cellular radar
     echoes, the winds formed rear-to-front currents. Increasing in volume and speed,
     the rear-to-front currents developed into meso- scale and penetrated toward
     the lower front and lower south of the systems. Consequently, the rear-to-front
     currents caused strong meso--scale convergence and the enhancement of
     updrafts at their leading edges. The transport of the band-parallel momentum
     greatly contributed to the successive development of new connective cells within
     the systems and the organization of the meso--scale systems in the snowband.
     Ice/snow particles were transported by the updrafts toward the rear and north of
     the systems in the overlying stable layer. They then evaporated outside the clouds.
     The downdraft caused by evaporative cooling played an important role in the
     transport of band-parallel momentum from the upper to the lower levels and from
     the outside to the inside of the snowband.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To report on Dual-Doppler Radar Study of Longitudinal-Mode Snowbands. Part I: A Three-Dimensional Kinematic Structure of Meso--Scale Connective Cloud Systems within a Longitudinal-Mode Snowband

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: None Planned

metadata.title: Seward (GAK4) Moorings
metadata.description:
Two moorings, one physical, one biological, 60 km offshore of Seward on the Gulf of Alaska shelf (GAK station 4). Physical: 100, 150, 200 m: CTD (micro-cats); 100 m: upward and downward ADCP's. Biological: PAR; 13 and 35m: PAR, transmissometer, fluorometer, SeaCat CTD, nitrate analyzer, 100 m: sediment trap This project also includes: Terry Whitledge, University of Alaska Fairbanks and Susan Henrichs, University of Alaska Fairbanks
An NPMR project
metadata.notes:
Purpose: Investigate effects of physical forcing on biological parameters such as nutrients, chlorophyll and sinking of particulate matter. NPMR project "Physical Forcing of Marine Productivity: monitoring moorings on the Gulf of Alaska Shelf.

Sampled months varied through the years but were usually during January, February, March, April, May, and October.  Salinity, temperature, and UV vector data were collected at various depths throughout the years using instruments such as MicroCAT, MTR. RCM-7, RCM-9, and SEACAT.  190m was the maximum bottom depth.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To collect physical oceanographic properties at and near the mooring locations.

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: Unknown

Access constraints: Contact Source.

Use constraints: Check with Source.

metadata.title: Subsurface Mooring Data from Gore Point, Gulf of Alaska: Station Gore Point 36
metadata.description: Subsurface mooring data from Gore Point, Gulf of Alaska: Station Gore Point 36.  Data were collected from 1994 through 2004.  Sampled months varied through the years but were usually during February, May, and September.  Salinity, temperature, UV vector, and velocity data were collected at various depths throughout the years using instruments such as ADCP, MicroCAT, RCM-4, and RCM-9.  183m was the maximum bottom depth.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To collect physical oceanographic properties at and near the mooring locations.

metadata.title: A Basin-wide Retrospective Analysis of Growth and Survival Patterns in Pink and Chum Salmon.
metadata.description:
The goal of this research is to understand factors affecting salmon stock dynamics in the Subarctic Pacific and its marginal seas, identified as a central issue by the North
Pacific Marine Research program. The approach is a retrospective study of growth and survival of chum and pink salmon stocks from diverse locations including western Alaska. The operating hypothesis is that, because fluctuating ocean climate differs from
west to east in the historical record, salmon productivity (growth and survival) should also have varied concordantly, both in historical and spatial scales. Over thirty years of data suitable for testing this hypothesis and alternatives are available in archives of
production statistics and scales. The method will entail retrospective time series analyses of salmon production and climate variation and will entail an analysis of spatial patterns of salmon production. Through this analysis we expect to identify factors affecting growth and survival of salmon from different parts of their range across the Subarctic Pacific.

This project also includes;

William Smoker 
University of Alaska Fairbanks 

William Heard 
Auke Bay Laboratory, Alaska Fisheries Science Center, NOAA 

Peter Hagen 
Alaska Department of Fish and Game 
peterh@adfg.state.ak.us


Collaborators include Masahide Kaeriyama of Hokkaido Tokai
University, and Leonid Klyashtorin, VINRO, Russian Federation.
An NPMR project
metadata.notes:
Purpose: A proposal sent to NPMR "A basin-wide retrospective analysis of growth and survival patterns in pink and chum salmon."

Status: Planned

Maintenance frequency: Unknown

Use constraints: Unknown

metadata.title: ALACE (Autonomous LAgrangian Current Explorer)
metadata.description: Data collected from neutrally buoyant, autonomous drifters and profilers, which record temperature and salinity data at preprogrammed depths for 10 days, rise to the  water surface recording temperature and salinity, transmit the information and their locations to an orbiting satellite before returning to depth and continuing another cycle. The satellite relays the data to land-based receiving stations for processing. Will eventually constitute part of ARGO, a global network of similar floats.
keywords: North Inner Coast (QCS, Hecate, Dixon Inlet and passages)
South Inner Coast (Johnstone, Georgia, JDF, inlets and passages)

metadata.title: PROBES: Processes and Resources Of the eastern Bering Sea shelf
metadata.description: The stimulus for Processes and Resources of the Eastern Bering Sea Shelf (PROBES) was a mutual US - Japan scientific concern about the ability of the Bering Sea to support the huge annual catch, on a sustained basis, of groundfish, pelagic fish, crab and other marine resources.  The question was large enough to demand the attention of oceanographic disciplines from both countries as well as from others.  After several conferences, it was decided to emphasize the "Golden Triangle" (the are encompassed southeastern Bering Sea shelf in an attempt to understand the bioproductivity of this region (Hood and Kelley 1974, Hood and Takenouti 1975).  In the beginning, it appeared most expedient, for logistic and funding reasons, to have each country pursue its part of the program independently.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: A report on PROBES: Processes and Resources Of the eastern Bering Sea shelf

FGDC metadata standard: FGDC Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata (version: FGDC-STD-001-1998)

metadata.title: The BERPAC Project: Development and Overview of Ecological Investigations in the Bering and Chukchi
metadata.description:
The following basic objective were formulated:

1)  Investigation of oceanographic and hydrochemcial processes in the Bering and    
     Chukchi sea ecosystems.

2)  Study the biological processes occurring in the pelagic and benthic environments.

3)  Study of the biogeochemcical cycles of contaminants and assessment of the 
     ecological consequences of pollution in the Bering and Chukchi Seas.

4)   Study of the processes determining the assimilative capacity of arctic marine 
      ecosystems in respect to contaminants.

5)  Assessment of ecological consequences of other anthropogenic impacts, including 
     possible climate changes, in the Bering and Chukchi seas.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: A report on the BERPAC Project:  Development and Overview of Ecological Investigations in the Bering and Chukchi

metadata.description: Includes (but are not limited to:) (1) Alaska Board of Fisheries and Fishery Management council reports (2) Season summaries (3) White papers (4) management plans (5) annual test fish results (6) legislative reports (7) forecast (8) area management reports (9) annual shellfish surveys (10) some annual U.S./Canada;  and since the 1993, the following studies have been published in this series:  (11) Salmon abundance, catch and escapements studies (12) annual smolt reports (13) tagging studies and (14) special short-term or interim reports on equipment or methodologies, stock identification, management, life history, etc..
metadata.notes:
Purpose: This series is primarily informational, serving to: (1) promote intradepartmental exchange of information and (2) meet ad hoc reporting functions of the department to other agencies, governmental and regulatory bodies, the fishing industry and the public.  Reports in this series may achieve original observations (raw data) or contain preliminary or incomplete data.  These reports do not receive full editorial and peer review.  Reports may be highly individualized.

metadata.title: Line P (PERD Project) - Oceanic carbon dioxide, 1988-present
metadata.description: Observations of large-scale changes in oceanic PC02 and supporting data of oceanographic properties and carbonate chemistry. May also include other lines and other projects (Line Z, Line R, Line PE, JGOFS, WOCE, Seamounts, Alaskan Gyre, Eddy, ).
keywords: South Inner Coast (Johnstone, Georgia, JDF, inlets and passages)
metadata.notes:
Purpose: Determination of the penetration of CO2 into the water column.

Supplemental Information: Risk Justification: Custodian will be leaving soon and has a large quantity of data not secured in a regional data centre.
Risk of Loss: High
Impact Justification: Long term time series (more than 10 years)
Impact of Loss: High
Recommended Action: Obtain access to data and bring to archives
Additional Info: Freon data have been partly published; data will be made available after publication. PCO2 data (1973-1999) have been sent to the OSAP archive. Much of the productivity and chlorophyll data have been published, will be made available. DOC data are in press, and will be made available. DON data have been written up into a paper which has not yet been submitted for publication. TCO2 and Talkalinity profiles have been made available (1972-1997) and TCO2 and Talkalinity surface data (1972-1990) have been made available. C13 and O-18 data are custody of C.S. Wong.
Storage Requirements: 50MB+unknown

Status: In work

Maintenance frequency: None planned

Access constraints: May Be Private

Use constraints: Temperature, salinity, dissolved oxygen, and nutrient data are stored on the OSAP database, Departmentally accessible. Other data will be available after publication/quality checked (see Additional Information, below)

Data quality - Logical consistency: Standardization of chemical instrumentation with known or commercially prepared standards.
Data quality - Completeness: Dataset Complications: Some DOC data are questionable.
 Meteorological data from NOAA buoy at Station P no longer freely available. Portable met. station on ship gives apparent measures of wind speed and direction for PCO2, must be corrected for ship`s heading, speed, etc.
PCO2 originally measured by IR spectrophotometer, then by gas chromatograph, now using a non-dispersive IR analyzer.
C13 and O-18 data are custody of C.S. Wong.
Electronic Data Complications: Temperature, salinity, oxygen and nutrient data on IOS archived database are not quite conforming to IOS Header format, and are therefore difficult to search. All of the magtapes are older than their guaranteed physical lifespan. The last attempt to retrieve data from a magtape was successful (July 7, 2000).

metadata.title: Marine Ecosystem Observatories (MEOS)
metadata.description: Fisheries and Oceans Canada and Environment Canada jointly maintain a network of weather buoys in the coastal and offshore waters of British Columbia. The existing weather buoys offer a geographically widespread network for observing the state of B.C.'s coastal ocean and any changes in marine ecosystems resulting from changing climate. The two departments are now working towards the concept of Marine Ecosystem ObServatories (MEOS) , adding new instruments to the buoys for measurements of ocean water properties and key biological fields.The first MEOS buoy has been placed in Saanich Inlet, near the Institute of Ocean Sciences, with easy access for testing and calibrating new sensors and methods. As resources become available, the instruments tested in Saanich Inlet may be added to other buoys in the existing AES/FOC network, or in other specialized locations such as Marine Protected Areas.
keywords: South Inner Coast (Johnstone, Georgia, JDF, inlets and passages)

metadata.title: Bering Sea FOCI
metadata.description: Bering Sea Fisheries-Oceanography Coordinated Investigations (BS FOCI) was a coastal fisheries ecosystems project of NOAA's Coastal Ocean Program (Boyles and Scavia 1993, Wenzel and Scavia 1993) from 1991 through 1997.  BS FOCI was established to seek understanding of the factors that control abundance of fish populations, with a specific goal of reducing uncertainty in resource management decisions through ecological research on walleye Pollock and stock structure in the Bering Sea.  Using a competitive process, BS FOCI awarded research components to academic scientists from several universities and to scientists from NOAA's Alaska Fisheries Science Center and Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory.  BS FOCI developed collaborations with Russian, Korean and Japanese scientists.  The National research Council (1994) reviewed accomplishments and plans of  BS FOCI.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To describe what Bering Sea Fisheries-Oceanography Coordinated Investigations (FOCI)  is and it's purpose.

Ships included the Whitethroat, the Oshawa, the Endeavor, the Parizeau, the Vector, the Pandora II, and others. metadata.title: Ocean Station Papa Detailed Zooplankton Data 1956 - 1980
metadata.description: The purpose of this document is to make the detailed data on Zooplankton samples available to the scientific community in electronic format and to provide a convenient reference for citing the detailed data. Zooplankton samples were collected at Ocean Station P from 1956 to 1980 and were analyzed to various levels of taxonomic resolution over the years. The dataset has reformatted detailed data, any errors discovered corrected and extra information added to produce one complete dataset for the whole sampling period. This dataset contains total zooplankton wet weights/m3 for the whole period 1956 to 1980, as well as densities for five major taxa (copepods, chaetognaths, euphausiids, amphipods and Aglantha) from 1964 to 1967 and species identifications, counts and lengths for many samples collected between 1968 to 1980. Document comes with a diskette containing the corrected detailed zooplankton data, methods used to collect and process the data and other pertinent information about the data.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: Supports scientific and environmental research.

metadata.title: United States Oil and Gas Exploration in the Bering Sea

creators.name: region, U.S. Minerals Management Service - Alaska Outer Continental shelf

metadata.description: The Bering Sea Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) held great interest for the oil companies as OCS leasing accelerated in the United States following the 1973 oil embargo.  The U.S. Department of the Interior's Minerals Management Service (MMS) has held four OCS lease sales in the Bering Sea.  More than $100 million has been spent on environmental studies to support OCS lease-sale proposals in the Bering Sea region.  Major issues and concerns associated with OCS exploration activities have been identified and migrated.  Twenty-four exploratory wells have been drilled without finding commercial quantities of oil or gas.  Except for the North Aleutian basin, where there have been no exploration drilling, there is limited interest in future near-term leasing and exploration opportunities in the Bering Sea OCS.  The MMS environmental studies effort has been significantly reduced in the Bering Sea, with the exception of completion of certain studies and monitoring of protected species as part of other ongoing studies.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: A report on the US Oil and Gas Exploration in the Bering Sea

metadata.description: Data collected by DFO to monitor the effects on Rupert and Holdberg Inlets of Island Copper Mines, located off Rupert Inlet. This included oceanographic and biological data in a custom, commercial software format (AQUAMIN). The data set was offered to IOS before the mine closed, but was not obtained. FGDC metadata date: 20040609
FGDC metadata standard: FGDC Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata (version: FGDC-STD-001-1998)

metadata.title: Summary of TINRO Ecosystem Investigations in the Bering Sea
metadata.description: Investigation in the Bering Sea were carried out by the Pacific Research Institute of Fisheries and Oceanography (TINRO) from an ecological point of view.  The composition, structure, interannual dynamics and function of the pelagic and demersal communities were studied on a macroecosystem scale.  This work was primarily undertaken by the Laboratory of Applied Biocenology (I.e. ecology) and the Laboratory of Research of Plankton of Far-Eastern Seas.  Ecosystem investigations were included as part of fishery research and were supported by a research vessel.  The mission of the first expedition in 1983 was conducted until 1985, with pelagic surveys starting after 1986.  Eleven expeditions have been completed.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: A report summarizing TINRO Ecosystem Investigations in the Bering Sea

metadata.title: Summary, Conclusions and Recommendations Related to the Bering Sea
metadata.description: Much of the interest in dynamics in the Bering Sea, now and in the past, has been spurred by concerns over the stability and sustainability of its vast living resources.  Particularly prominent today are depressed populations of several species of marine mammals, notably great whales, Steller sea lions, fur seals, harbor seals and sea otters and of additional species of considerable economic importance, such as king crabs, shrimp and Pacific Ocean perch.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: A report on the summary, conclusions and recommendations related to the Bering Sea

metadata.title: Ship of Opportunity: Canada to Japan - 1980-present
metadata.description: Data from merchant ships travelling between British Columbia and Japan, from 1980-1990 (Canada Ace), 1995 to 2000, continuing (Skaugran), and 1999-2000, continuing (Alligator Hope). Data collected include surface total carbon dioxide, alkalinity, nutrients, chlorophyll a, carbon-13 in seawater, and atmospheric carbon-13. Underway measurements include position, time, temperature and salinity. Skaugran samples and data were collected 3-4 times daily by scientific staff and once daily by ship`s engineers until 1999, then were reduced to daily engineer`s samples. Alligator Hope samples were collected 3 times daily.

FGDC metadata date: 20040609
FGDC metadata standard: FGDC Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata (version: FGDC-STD-001-1998)

metadata.title: The 1987 Bristol Bay Survey and the Bristol Bay Halibut Fishery, 1990 - 1992
metadata.description:
Bristol Bay is considered a nursery area for Pacific halibut and was closed to
     commercial halibut fishing from 1967 to 1989. In the summer of 1987 the
     International Pacific Halibut Commission (IPHC) conducted a survey in
     Bristol Bay to assess the commercial stock size of halibut and the incidence of
     sublegal fish. Three vessels fished the coastal area from Cape Newenham to
     Cape Seniavin. The catch per unit effort was 6 pounds, well below the catch
     per unit effort observed in other areas of the Bering Sea. The catch of
     sublegal halibut was low; less than 0.5 halibut per unit effort. The survey
     results suggested that a limited commercial fishery in Bristol Bay would not
     have an adverse impact on juvenile stocks. The IPHC extended the regulatory
     Area 4E boundary to allow commercial fishing in Bristol Bay in 1990. Fishing
     success has been poor compared to other areas and the number of vessels
     reporting landings in the fishery decreased from 97 in 1990 to 19 in 1992.
     Annual Bristol Bay catches have ranged from 14,000 to 26,000 pounds.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To report the 1987 Bristol Bay survey and the Bristol Bay halibut fishery, 1990 - 1992

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: None Planned

metadata.title: Thermohaline Oscillations in the LSG OGCM: Propagating Anomalies and Sensitivity to Parameterizations
metadata.description:
New experiments are reported that extend previous studies of the internally generated variability found when the Hamburg LSG Ocean General Circulation Model is integrated under mixed  boundary conditions. All model integrations have stochastic forcing added to the freshwater flux to  excite the variability. It is demonstrated that the salinity anomalies that propagate around the meridional circulation of the Atlantic Ocean are merely signals emitted from the source of the variability in the Southern Ocean; they do not play an active role in its generation. It is the Southern Ocean flipﾖflop oscillator, as suggested by a previous study, that is the driving mechanism of the 320-yr period oscillations. A second mode of propagation is identified that may be related to the
periodicity of the oscillations: westward propagation of upper-ocean salinity anomalies around the coast of Antarctica. It is shown that this mode is driven by the same density-upwelling wave motion as reported elsewhere in the literature.

       The sensitivity of the simulated variability to changes in some of the modelﾒs numerical and physical algorithms is investigated. The computationally expensive step of retriangularizing the  matrix equation for the barotropic velocity can be done very infrequently without affecting the characteristics of the variability. Changing to a connective overturn parameterization that leaves  fewer residual instabilities has a small effect on the variability, while changing to one that mixes,  rather than interchanges, statically unstable water masses can reduce the magnitude of the  variability by up to 70%. The latter change, however, is attributed entirely to the different  freshwater flux forcing that the new parameterization implies. Using a more realistic haline and
thermal coupling between sea ice and the ocean also leads to greatly reduced internal variability on  the 320-yr timescale. Again, changes in surface fluxes implied by the alteration to the model are important, and these changes have implications for the flux adjustments necessary when the LSG  model is coupled to an atmosphere model. The results presented here indicate considerable scope for reducing such flux adjustments.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To report on the Thermohaline Oscillations in the LSG OGCM: Propagating Anomalies and Sensitivity to Parameterizations

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: None Planned
