metadata.title: Role of the Bering Strait in Controlling North Atlantic Ocean Circulation and Climate
metadata.description:
Recent climate records from ice cores and deep-sea sediments suggest that
        there has been considerable climate variability in the North Atlantic region
        over the past 250,000 years. Much of this variability may be linked to changes
        in thermohaline circulation in the North Atlantic ocean. Model studies have
        demonstrated that changes in the flux of fresh water to the ocean, resulting
        from changes in atmospheric transport or the waxing and waning of ice sheets,
        can have a significant effect on the thermohaline circulation. The authors
        present model simulations showing that increased flow of fresher North Pacific
        water through the Bering Strait into the northern North Atlantic can also
        effect the thermohaline circulation, by suppressing North Atlantic Deep Water
        formation; however, decreased flow does not necessarily cause deep-water
        formation to begin again. In the model, flow through the Bering Strait
        depends on ecstatic sea level and the salinity difference between the North
        Atlantic and North Pacific oceans. The authors suggest that a higher sea level
        during the last interglacial period, leading to greater flow through the Bering
        Strait, may have made the North Atlantic thermohaline circulation more
        sensitive than it is at present to fluctuations in the hydrological cycle, which
        may explain recent observations indicating that climate variability was greater
        then than it is today.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To show the role of the Bering Strait in controlling North Atlantic Ocean circulation and climate

metadata.title: Copper River Basin Subsistence

creators.name: AHTNA/Copper River Native Association contract to Institute

metadata.description: Data Type: Subsistence/Traditional Knowledge;   This dataset is a multi-layered subsistence database pulling together existing data sources. Layers include drainage, hypsography, supplemental hypsography, political boundaries and ocean net, populated places, park boundaries, land selection status, 1:250,000 USGS Quadrangle boundaries,  Ahtna Clan boundaries, native corporation boundaries, traditional use, Ahtna place names, Native routes, registered traplines, trapping areas, woodcutting areas4/88, hunting areas, fishing, boating, and camping areas, wood cutting areas 3/86, hunting areas 3/86, subsistence hunt areas for large mammals, Game Management Units ADF&G. Intended use of information is to aid CRNA meet criteria to establish permanent rights for Ahtna shareholders to pursue subsistence activities in Wrangell St. Elias National Park and preserve and protect Ahtna subsistence use areas and resources from urban competition. This database is part of a cooperative agreement with NPS and BLM to develop information relevant to Customary and Traditional Use determinations, the establishment of Residential Zones for subsistence use in the park and to establish a roster of eligible subsistence users in the Park/Preserve under section 1344 of ANILCA. Copies of the final dataset will reside at BLM, Ahtna, Copper River Native Assoc., and NPS. Some layers of this dataset have been extracted as separate records in the metadata database as they represent data that was automated as a result of this dataset compilation and are new electronic products. See metadata record #118,119,116, and 117.

metadata.title: 97-02 1996  Bristol Bay Staff Meeting Minutes.  October 14 - 15, 1996, Anchorage Regional Office.  Beverly Cross.  January  1997.  80 pp.
metadata.description: Includes (but are not limited to:) (1) Alaska Board of Fisheries and Fishery Management council reports (2) Season summaries (3) White papers (4) management plans (5) annual test fish results (6) legislative reports (7) forecast (8) area management reports (9) annual shellfish surveys (10) some annual U.S./Canada;  and since the 1993, the following studies have been published in this series:  (11) Salmon abundance, catch and escapements studies (12) annual smolt reports (13) tagging studies and (14) special short-term or interim reports on equipment or methodologies, stock identification, management, life history, etc..
metadata.notes:
Purpose: This series is primarily informational, serving to: (1) promote intradepartmental exchange of information and (2) meet ad hoc reporting functions of the department to other agencies, governmental and regulatory bodies, the fishing industry and the public.  Reports in this series may achieve original observations (raw data) or contain preliminary or incomplete data.  These reports do not receive full editorial and peer review.  Reports may be highly individualized.

metadata.title: Copper River Delta Community Classification Field Plots
metadata.description: Data Type: Vegetation/Land Cover/Soils;  The database consists plot information collected in 1993-94 by The Alaska Natural Heritage program under a cooperative agreement with the Chugach National Forest to develop a hierarchical classification of community types, describe the successional plant community sequences, and landcover associations for the Copper River Delta. Plot information was collected by trained field crews and georeferenced to 1:63,360 and 1:60,000 CIR air photos. 286 plots were used to create the classification. These data points reside in a paradox database format. The intended use of these data were used to develop and support the community type classification for the area for use by the U.S.  Forest Service. These data have not been put in a GIS system but are GIS ready.

metadata.title: Copper River Delta Moose Habitat

creators.name: Service, U.S. Natural Resource Conservation Service formerly Soil Conservation

metadata.description: Data Type: Vegetation/Land Cover/Soils;  This data set depicts a cross section of the Western Copper River Delta vegetation types, spanning from the mountains to the coast mapped on 1959-1986 aerial photography. A broad classification scheme used separates forest, scrub, herbaceous, and aquatic types. Polygons were digitized using Carto Instruments software and analyzed using ARC/INFO software. Generated acreage calculations of types over time are used to evaluate spatial juxtaposition of vegetation types.

metadata.title: DMSP F8 SSM/I Monthly Averaged Sea Ice Concentration Grids

creators.name: National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC)

metadata.description:
DMSP F8 SSM/I Monthly Averaged Sea Ice Concentration for the Polar Regions 
for July 1987 through December 1991 were produced by NSIDC using the daily
sea ice concentration grids which were generated using the NASATEAM 
algorithm (Cavalieri, et al. 1986, JGR 91(C1), p. 975-994) and distributed
on CD-ROM by NSIDC.  The monthly sea ice grids are available on request
via ftp (see access instructions below), and may eventually be distributed 
on CD-ROM with other SSM/I products.  The monthly sea ice grids can be used 
as a mask to block out ice-covered areas for various applications.  To 
accommodate as many  potential applications as possible, the monthly averaged 
ice extent was delineated using four concentration values (0%, 5%, 10%, and 
15%) for the minimum concentrations included in the averages.  The grids are 
8-bit raster images containing 448 lines of 304 pixels (304x by 448y) for the
northern hemisphere and 332 lines of 316 pixels (316x by 332y) for the
southern.  IDL procedures were used to calculate monthly averages from the
daily-averaged SSM/I grids.  The data were then put into Hierarchical Data
Format (HDF).  Utilities to read and manipulate HDF data are available via
ftp from the National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA).  The
NCSA ftp server address is ftp.ncsa.uiuc.edu; help is available from
helphdf@ncsa.uiuc.edu.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To report on the  Monthly Averaged Sea Ice Concentration for the Polar Regions 
for July 1987 through December 1991 were produced by NSIDC using the daily
sea ice concentration grids which were generated using the NASATEAM 
algorithm (Cavalieri, et al. 1986, JGR 91(C1), p. 975-994) and distributed
on CD-ROM by NSIDC.

Status: Complete

metadata.title: Land Cover/Vegetation - PWS, Copper River
metadata.description: Data Type: Vegetation/Land Cover/Soils;  This data layer is a composite of vegetation and land cover data encompassing all of Prince William Sound and the Copper River drainage and eastern portions of the Kenai Peninsula. Original data sources include the Chugach National Forest Timber Type database, Interim Land Cover Program and Copper River Land Cover images from USGS EROS Alaska Field Office, and the Alaska Land and Resource Mapping System (ALARM) from the Alaska Department of Natural Resources (DNR). All of the original datasets were generalized; merged, and classified according to the Alaska Vegetation Classification, resulting in a generalized layer that broadly characterizes vegetation patterns throughout the area. Characteristics of the original data bases are outlined below; the data sets used to create this composite vegetation layer are documented separately The Chugach NF Timber Type database is a timber oriented vegetation layer based on interpretation of aerial photography. It is the most detailed digital vegetation information available for substantial areas within the greater Prince William Sound ecosystem. The database contains detailed information about timbered areas including species composition, stand density, stocking levels, stand class size, and volume. Many of these timber-oriented descriptions can be useful as surrogates for important ecological variables such as structural information about a given stand. The database also contains less detailed information on non- forest vegetation and cover types. Both the Interim Land Cover and Copper River Land Cover datasets are based on Landsat Multispectral Sensor (MSS) satellite imagery with an original resolution of 80 meters. The Copper River Land Cover data contains more detailed information on shrub and herbaceous communities than the Interim Land Cover Program and the Chugach NF Timber Type datasets. The ALARM datasets are based in part on interpretation of Landsat MSS imagery and aerial photography but have been generalized considerably; the minimum mapping unit used in the ALARM program was 640 acres. Each dataset used to compile this data layer uses a different vegetation classification scheme, a result of intended use and method of data automation. All but the Chugach National Forest Timber Type database use modifications of the Alaska Vegetation Classification scheme (Viereck et al. 1992). Pacific GIS developed a cross-walk from the vegetation types in each data source to the closest equivalent vegetation type in the Alaska Vegetation Classification scheme to provide a common classification that can be used across the ecosystem.

metadata.title: DMSP F8 Special Sensor Microwave/Imager (SSM/I) Sea Ice Concentration Grids for the Polar Regions on CD-ROM

creators.name: National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC)

metadata.description:
DMSP F8 SSM/I ice concentrations are daily first-year, multi-year, and 
total ice, 25 x 25 km polar stereographic grids, north and south polar 
regions, output from two algorithms: NASA Team algorithm (Cavalieri et 
al. 1986; 1994 in prep.), and Comiso "Bootstrap" algorithm (Comiso 1994
in prep.).  Input data are orbital antenna temperatures processed to gridded 
brightness temperatures.  Defense Meteorological Satellite Program (DMSP) 
F8 platform carried this first functional Special Sensor Microwave/Imager 
instrument, a linearly-polarized passive microwave radiometric system at 
85.5 GHz V/H, 37.0 GHz V/H, 22.2 GHz V, 19.3 GHz V/H. Two CD-ROMs contain 
all F8 SSM/I ice concentrations, 9 July 1987 - 31 December 1991 (NP 
files = 137202 bytes, SP files = 105922 bytes, in HDF.  Software to read
and manipulate HDF are available from National Center for Supercomputing
Applications (NCSA) via ftp (ftp.ncsa.uiuc.edu). Other public domain and 
commercial software packages, such as IDL, are available that can read and 
manipulate HDF.  SSM/I CD-ROMs are presently being distributed at no charge, 
with first priority for the NASA and NASA-funded research communities.  
This distribution policy is subject to change without notice; please inquire.  
NSIDC is processing DMSP F11 SSM/I in the same grid/projection.

The primary archive and distribution source for DMSP SSM/I swath
(orbital) data (level 1b) is NOAA/NESDIS Satellite Data Services Division,
Princeton Executive Square, Room 100, Washington, DC 20233; telephone
301-763-8402.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To show the DMSP F8 Special Sensor Microwave/Imager (SSM/I) Sea Ice Concentration Grids for the Polar Regions on CD-ROM

metadata.title: Vegetation Developed Using ALARM (Alaska Land And Resources Mapping Program)

creators.name: Service, U.S. Natural Resource Conservation Service formerly Soil Conservation

metadata.description: Data Type: Vegetation/Land Cover/Soils;  Vegetation developed using Alaska Land And Resources Mapping Program (ALARM). Pacific GIS used several different full resolution vegetation datasets organized by 1:250,000 scale USGS quadrangles to cover the Prince William Sound - Copper River ecosystem. This data set, developed by the Alaska Department of Natural Resources (DNR) was created to assist in region wide planning efforts. Pacific GIS developed a cross-walk from the original vegetation codes to the closest equivalent vegetation type in the Alaska Vegetation Classification scheme to provide a common classification that can be used across the ecosystem for various sources of vegetation data. This common classification is included along with the original classification.

Pacific GIS developed a cross-walk from the interim land cover vegetation types to the closest equivalent vegetation type in the Alaska Vegetation Classification scheme to provide a common classification that can be used across the ecosystem for various sources of vegetation data. This common classification has been added to the original classification information.

metadata.title: Wrangell-Elias Vegetation Ground Plots
metadata.description: Data Type:  ;  Spatially referenced vegetation ground plot data collected over a 12 year period throughout Wrangell St. Elias National Park. Vegetative species information and related canopy cover data was collected from ground plots. Plots have been classified using the Alaska Vegetation Classification Scheme. All plots have been referenced on Alaska High Altitude Color Infrared photography at 1:63360 scale. The collection of this data was supported by the regional fire program to provide ground information as to fire fuels for Wrangell St. Elias National Park. These plots have been used for other applications as supportive information for landcover mapping, habitat interpretations, general vegetation knowledge, etc. A Vegetation Survey effort has been underway at the park for approximately 12 years and recently has expanded. Rare plant surveys are currently being conducted as well. All collection points are now spatially referenced with GPS systems.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: Unknown

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: Unknown

Access constraints: Unknown

Use constraints: Data is spatially located on color infrared aerial photography and has not yet been automated in a GIS system. Attribute data has been automated by Wrangell St. Elias National Park in database management system.

metadata.title: Coastal Bathymetry of the Bering, Chukchi and Beaufort Seas
metadata.description: Bathymetric contours were generated from soundings collected by National Ocean Service vessels from 1900 to 1971. The 1:250,000 maps are available for U.S. coastal waters. Bathymetric contours are in meters, with 10 meter intervals out to 200 m, supplemented by 2 m contours. Beyond 200 m, contours are at 50 m intervals to maximum depth. The GIS database derived from these maps includes the Bering, Chukchi, and Beaufort Seas in western and northern Alaska. Approximately 100 maps.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: The Bathymetric Map series was developed to provide detailed contours of underwater features. The maps serve as a basic tool for performing scientific, engineering, marine geophysical, and marine environmental studies. The maps were not intended to be used for navigation.

metadata.title: Coastline Alaska Canada
metadata.description: Data Type: Coastline;  This coastline coverage was extracted from an image processing system that uses the digital chart of the world coastline for georeferencing satellite images. The data have a scale of 1:1000000. The vectors pertaining to the greater Arctic Refuge and portions of Canada were extracted, rebuilt with line topology and projected into Albers Conic Equal Area projection.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: These data provide a generalized coastline for the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, suitable for general resource evaluation purposes.

metadata.description: Data Type:  ;  This dataset depicts the greater Arctic National Wildlife Refuge coastline at a sourcescale of 1:63360. This dataset was derived from USGS 1:63360 scale maps combined with data from the ESRI Digital Chart of the World, Alaska subset. The attributes associated with this ARC/INFO dataset are identical to those of the Digital Chart of the World. The final dataset is in an Albers Equal Area map projection.

metadata.title: Terrain Units of the Arctic Refuge Coastal Plain (Walker, D.A.)
metadata.description: Data Type: TERRAIN UNITS;   This dataset is a digital depiction of the Walker, 1983 terrain unit mapping of the Arctic Refuge coastal plain. Five terrain unit types were described for a major portion of the 1002 study area of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. Each terrain unit delineates a combined characterization of dominant soils, landforms and vegetation types. Portions of the map were extended geographically, using LANDSAT TM interpretations and aerial photography. Two original terrain classes, Floodplains and Hilly Coastal plain, were further subdivided into east and west for USFWS purposes of this dataset.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: These data provide a depiction of terrain units that combine a characterization of soils, landforms, and vegetation. These data were integrated as ancillary data in the spectral analysis of the 1994 USFWS 1002 TM LANDSAT Landcover map for the 1002 study area. This dataset is useful for a variety of resource applications, resource evaluations and habitat analysis.

Status: In Progress

metadata.title: Response of Sea Ice Drift to Wind Forcing on the Northeastern Newfoundland Shelf
metadata.description:
Observations of sea ice drift obtained with satellite-tracked ice beacons in
     March-April of 1988 and 1989 have been used to examine the response of
     sea ice drift to wind forcing over the northern Newfoundland continental shelf.
     The short-term (5-20 days) response of sea ice drift ranges from 2.6 to 5.4%
     of the local wind over much of the inner continental shelf, which is comparable
     to that in the Bering Sea and the Antarctic but larger than that in Arctic. Sea
     ice drifts to the right of the local wind, at angles ranging from 10 degree to 63
     degree . The response to wind forcing is largest near the ice edge, both over
     the middle portions of the shelf and along the southern margins of the seasonal
     ice zone and during strong and steady wind of several days' duration. The
     large wind-driven response of ice drift observed in this study, in comparison
     with the Arctic, may result from (1) reduced levels of internal ice stress
     associated with the generally thin ice cover and lower areal concentration of
     sea ice, (2) large atmospheric drag coefficients associated with the small ice
     floes in areas of comparatively higher ice concentration, and (3) smooth ice
     bottom caused by melting. In nearshore areas the ice to wind coupling is
     reduced owing to larger internal ice stresses experienced locally due to ice
     pileup.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To report on the response of sea ice drift to wind forcing on the northeastern Newfoundland shelf

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: None Planned

metadata.title: DMSP-F11 Monthly Sea Ice Concentration Grids for the Polar Regions

creators.name: National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC)

metadata.description:
DMSP F11 monthly averaged sea ice concentration grids in the polar 
stereographic projection are produced based on daily sea ice concentration 
grids generated using the NASA Team algorithm. Processing is continuous 
beginning 3 December 1991,  and continues the series begun with F8 monthly 
averaged data. Although a high degree of correlation exists between F8 and F11 
data (Abdalati et al. 1995), regression coefficients (NSIDC 1995) have been 
applied in deriving F11 daily ice concentrations, which form the basis for 
this data set. Monthly averaged data files contain ice concentration in 
percent ranging from 0% to 100%. Then, ice concentrations are delineated 
using 0%, 5%, 10% and 15% as the minimum concentrations included in the 
averages (e.g.: a 5% cutoff sets all data values between 1% and 5% to 0%). 
These four thresholds accommodate as many potential applications as possible. 
Grids are 8-bit raster images stored in HDF.  Data in compressed tar files are 
distributed via ftp, on sidads.colorado.edu (IP address 128.138.135.20).
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To report on the Monthly Sea Ice Concentration Grids for the Polar Regions

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: None Planned

metadata.title: Digital Chart of the World (DCW)
metadata.description: Data Type: Base Maps;   The DCW is a vector basemap of the world at a scale of 1:1,000,000 developed by ESRI for ARC/INFO. The database consists of geographic, attribute, and textual data that is divides the world into 2,094 fifteen by fifteen degree tiles that are each subdivided into five by five degree tiles. Over 200 attributes are included in 17 thematic layers. The DCW is 1.7 gigabytes in size distributed on four CD-ROMs. There is an Alaska module to this dataset that is available, that consists of all available layers covering only the State of Alaska. Grid-arendal Global Resource Information database sponsored by the United Nations have produced a similar subsection of the DCW for the polar region of the world, north of 45 degree latitude. The potential user will need to consult the DCW data dictionary for a complete review of database contents.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: Unknown

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: Unknown

Access constraints: The DCW is commercially available on ISO 9660 formatted CD-ROM discs from ESRI. Consult ESRI for latest database acquisition costs.

metadata.title: NOAA Nautical Charts
metadata.description: Data Type: Base Maps  ;Conventional flat nautical charts for navigation are assigned to different scale groups. Harbor Charts are 1:50,000 or larger and are intended navigation and anchorage. Coast Charts are 1:50,000 to 1:150,000 and are intended for coastwise navigation inside the offshore reefs and shoals, entering bays and harbors of considerable size, and navigating certain inland waterways. General Charts are 1:150,000 to 1:600,000 and are intended for use when a vessel's course is well offshore, but when its position can be fixed by landmarks, lights, buoys, and characteristic soundings. Nautical charts are in the process of being put into a raster format but are not yet available.

metadata.title: DMSP F11 Special Sensor Microwave Imager (SSM/I) Sea Ice Concentration Grids for the Polar Regions

creators.name: National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC)

metadata.description:
Group:  Summary DMSP-F11 daily, total and multi-year sea ice concentration
grids are derived from the SSM/I daily brightness temperatures.  With a
resolution of 25X25 km, these sea ice concentrations are presented as
raster images (HDF raster image sets, RIS) mapped to polar stereographic
projections depicting north and south polar regions. Data are stored in
HDF and packaged in compressed tar format. These ice concentrations
continue the series begun with DMSP-F8 SSM/I coverage, generated using the
NASA Team algorithm. Processing is continuous on the F11 data, beginning 3
December 1991.  The DMSP-F8 and -F11 data demonstrate a high degree of
correlation (Abdalati et al. 1995) although regression coefficients are
applied in the development of F11 ice concentrations in order to maintain
consistency of the data set (NSIDC 1995). Data are available via ftp
(sidads.colorado.edu, IP address 128.138.135.20).

metadata.title: Township Boundaries
metadata.description: Data Type: Base Maps  ;Township boundaries were generated using Bureau of Land Management's (BLM) computer programs for the construction of digital aliquot parts. The programs make calculations from the radian measurements representing township corner coordinates (AEH coordinate files). At the time when this version of the township coverage was constructed, both DNR and BLM stored their radian measurements to ten positions of accuracy. In general, this resulted in digital placement of the township lines within a meter of their protracted, NAD27, latitude-longitude positions.

metadata.title: USGS Digital Line Graphs
metadata.description: Data Type: Base Maps  ;Digital Line Graph (DLG) data are digital representations of cartographic information. DLG's of topographic and planimetric map features are derived from cartographic source materials using manual and automated digitizing methods. The USGS DLG data is classified as large (1:63,360) intermediate (1:1,000,000), and small (1:2,000,000) scale. Large-scale DLG data are available in nine categories: 1. hypsography, 2. hydrography, 3. vegetative surface cover, 4. non-vegetative features; 5. boundaries; 6. survey control markers; 7. transportation systems 8. manmade features, and 9. US Public Land Survey System, including township, range, and section information. Intermediate-scale DLG's are sold in five categories: 1. Public Land survey, 2. boundaries, 3. transportation 4. hydrography, and 5. hypsography. Small-scale DLG data are sold in three data categories: 1. boundaries; 2. transportation; 3. hydrography. All of these categories are also included on a 1:2,000,000-scale CD-ROM.

metadata.title: USGS Orthophoto Quads
metadata.description: Data Type: Base Maps  ; Orthophotos are multicolored, distortion-free, photographic images. Unlike a normal aerial photograph, relief displacement in orthophotos has been removed so that all ground features are displayed in their true ground position. This allows for the direct measurement of distance, areas, angles, and positions. An orthophoto displays features that may be omitted or generalized on maps. They serve a variety of purposes, from interim maps to field references for earth science investigations and analysis. Scale is 1:63,360.

metadata.description: Data Type: Base Maps  ; Topographic quadrangle maps at 1:250,000 scale. Terrain is portrayed by contour lines and features such as roads, towns, water areas, and vegetation are shown by map symbols and colors. metadata.title: Alaska Coastal Zone Boundaries
metadata.description: The database is a statewide depiction of Alaska's Coastal Zone boundaries, and State of Alaska Department of Fish and Game's associated boundary narratives, updated in 1994. An ARC/INFO AML has been developed that extracts single 1:250,000 USGS quadrangles subsets of data and reprojects it to UTM, allowing use of the data at this scale. Associated ASCII files linked to the INFO attribute file contains legal boundary descriptions for each quadrangle. Data is limited to use at a 1:250,000 scale or smaller and is intended for use at a regional or statewide scale for general planning purposes. Site specific evaluation of CZM boundaries should consult more detailed CZM District data sets existing in manual and some in automated form. The Habitat and Restoration Division of The Alaska Department of Fish and Game has a working copy of this data set that is utilized for the coastal zone permitting process.

metadata.title: Ease-Grid Brightness Temperatures

creators.name: National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC)

metadata.description:
The NOAA/NASA Pathfinder Program SSM/I Level 3 EASE-Grid Brightness 
Temperatures will consist of three series produced on CD-ROM, one series each for the EASE-Grid Northern Hemisphere, Southern Hemisphere and Cylindrical (global) projections. Grids represent spatially interpolated data. The interpolation technique maximizes the radiometric integrity of original brightness temperature values, maintain high spatial and temporal precision, and involve no averaging of original swath data. 

Coverage is global and spans the Pathfinder SSM/I Benchmark period, from
1 August 1987 through 30 November 1988.  Resolution is 25 km for all channels 
and 12.5 km for the 85 GHz channels. There are 18 brightness temperature files 
per day for a given projection (nine each for ascending and descending passes), 
and two (ascending and descending) corresponding time files. Data are contained
in flat binary files, either one image per file consisting of two-dimensional 2-byte integer arrays of brightness temperatures in tenths of Kelvins, or in the case of time files, two-dimensional 1-byte integer arrays consisting of GMT in tenths of hours. 

Data are available as processing is completed, with completion of the data set projected for the end of 1995. Data are available via ftp, on CD-ROM and through the Internet.  Contact NSIDC User Services for information.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To report on the EASE-GRID BRIGHTNESS TEMPERATURES

metadata.title: Generalized Land Status
metadata.description: Data Type: Boundaries  ; AKSTATUS is a statewide summary of land ownership in Alaska. It includes the major categories of state, native, and federal holdings. Activity on state land is recorded, by section, in DNR's Land Administration System (LAS). Note that this is not a parcel database. If parts of a single section fall into different ownership categories, then that section will contain multiple codes (see list below). Thus, a section may appear to have conflicting land status due to the resolution of the data (section on/section off), while at the parcel level, there would be no conflicting land status. Detailed maps by township (state status plats) portraying state land ownership are available at the Public Information Center, Department of Natural Resources. Similar maps (master title plats) portraying federal and native land ownership are available at the BLM Public Room, Bureau of Land Management. Please consult these maps for a more precise location of land ownership, and consult the public land record for current land status information.

metadata.title: Recording District Boundaries
metadata.description: Data Type: Boundaries  ; The Recording District Boundary coverage depicts the 34 recording districts established for the administration of the state's system for recording and filing of documents. These boundaries were created by the Alaska Court System as the Alaska Recording Districts Portfolio. The Portfolio dated September 1, 1964, was mandated by Alaska Supreme Court Order No. 12, Amendment No. 13, effective July 1, 1975. Recording district boundaries were originally depicted on 153 United States Geological Survey (USGS) quarter million quadrangle mylar maps, which are maintained by the Anchorage Recording District Office. The recording district boundaries are used to establish the locations in which any recorded public or private document must be recorded and filed. Due to consolidation, the state maintains documents for these 34 recording districts at only 14 filing locations throughout Alaska. All files and records within respective boundaries are maintained at the 14 filing location offices.

metadata.title: Alaska Regional Profiles
metadata.description: A series of six volumes covering Alaska that describe natural and manmade systems. An assembled Planning team made up of resource specialists prepared their respective resource summaries for each of six regions of the state. The sources are a combination of existing and original. Original maps prepared for evaluated resources are currently housed at the Alaska Resource library in the Anchorage Federal Building. General themes include climate, topography, geology, hydrology, soils, biotic communities, cultural resources, land status and services. The intended use of this information was to provide resource information for federal, state, and local planning efforts particularly for land selections under ANILCA. and reflect data current to early 1970's. Volumes 1-Southcentral Region and IV-Southeast Region are applicable to NBS Ecosystem Initiative areas.

metadata.title: Alaska Heritage Resources Survey
metadata.description: Data Type: Cultural Resources;   The Alaska Heritage Resource Survey (AHRS) is an inventory of all reported historic and prehistoric sites within the State of Alaska and is maintained by the office of History and Archeology. This inventory of cultural resources includes objects, structures, buildings, sites, districts, and travel ways with a general provision that they be over 50 years old. To date nearly 15,000 sites have been recorded within Alaska (however, this is probably only a small percentage of the sites which may actually exist but are as yet unreported.) The fundamental use of the AHRS is to protect cultural resource sites from unwanted destruction. Various state, federal and private entities use the inventory for planning and reviewing development projects. The AHRS is primarily a map based system.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: Unknown

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: Unknown

Access constraints: Access to site location information contained in the AHRS is closed to the general public.

metadata.title: USGS Digital Elevation Models 1:63,360
metadata.description: Data Type: Elevation  ; Digital Elevation Model (DEM) data consist of an array of regularly spaced elevations. DEM data in 15-minute units consist of regular arrays of elevations arranged horizontally to the coordinate system of NAD 27. The spacing between elevation along profiles is 2 arc seconds of latitude by 3 arc seconds of longitude. Each profile has 451 elevations. DEM data for 15-minute units correspond to the USGS 15-minute topographic quadrangle map series in Alaska. The unit sizes in Alaska vary depending on the latitude. Unit south of 59 degrees North cover 15x20-minute areas, those between 59 and 62 degrees North cover 15x22.5-minute areas.
metadata.notes:

metadata.title: Bering Sea Groundfish Database
metadata.description: This data set includes information obtained from Groundfish trawl surveys including cruise description, type of platform, time, sampling location, sampling gear, taxonomic composition of the catch, weight and number, sex and size, and more specialized observations that may include reproductive condition, age, and length-weight factors.  Some data on the U.S. Exclusive Economic Zone are also included.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: To recreate a Bering Sea Groundfish Data Base

metadata.title: 97-31 Report to the Alaska Board of Fisheries on the Stock Composition of Sockeye Salmon Catches Within East Bristol Bay Fishing Districts,  1983 - 1995.  Jim Menard and James D. Miller.  October  1997  159 pp.
metadata.description: Includes (but are not limited to:) (1) Alaska Board of Fisheries and Fishery Management council reports (2) Season summaries (3) White papers (4) management plans (5) annual test fish results (6) legislative reports (7) forecast (8) area management reports (9) annual shellfish surveys (10) some annual U.S./Canada;  and since the 1993, the following studies have been published in this series:  (11) Salmon abundance, catch and escapements studies (12) annual smolt reports (13) tagging studies and (14) special short-term or interim reports on equipment or methodologies, stock identification, management, life history, etc..
metadata.notes:
Purpose: This series is primarily informational, serving to: (1) promote intradepartmental exchange of information and (2) meet ad hoc reporting functions of the department to other agencies, governmental and regulatory bodies, the fishing industry and the public.  Reports in this series may achieve original observations (raw data) or contain preliminary or incomplete data.  These reports do not receive full editorial and peer review.  Reports may be highly individualized.

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: Annually

Access constraints: Requests for one or two pages of data and/or short reports can usually be accommodated.

Use constraints: Republications of materials in this report series may be authorized by the department

metadata.title: Anadromous Streams
metadata.description: Data Type: Fish  ; Data depicts upper and lower extent of Anadromous fish streams throughout Alaska and is updated regularly. ARC/INFO software is used to manage and update data. This dataset is used to produce the Anadromous Waters Catalog for Alaska. Many other Alaska Resource Management agencies are known to use this dataset within their own agencies, utilizing that subset that pertains to the lands under their jurisdiction. The U.S. Forest Service is known to utilize this dataset and the EXXON Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council has as well. Additionally, stream arcs are available for the EVOS area.

metadata.title: Coded Wire Tag Database - Salmon
metadata.description: Data Type: Fish  ; This database is used to evaluate hatchery practices and estimate hatchery contributions. It is used for in-season fisheries management and a variety of research and restoration activities. Fish are tracked from release to return. The database is part of the Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission coast wide database used to monitor salmonoid fish and steelhead as part of the US-Canada fisheries treaty.

metadata.title: Fisheries Information Management System
metadata.description: Data Type: Fish  ; Fisheries Information Management System (FIMS) is a prototype computer system that links data sets routinely used by fisheries managers. This system is a relational data base structure. The purpose of this data set is to provide scientists and fisheries access to public information that will aid them in forming their fisheries plans. The relational database structure uses ORACLE programming. Output products include tables, statistical presentation and graphics. This data is portable to a GIS system to include ARC/INFO and MAP/INFO. Datasets included in FIM are NMFS weekly processor reports, NMFS survey data, NMFS observer data, NMFS FOCI data (oceanographic/climate), ADF&G CFEC fish ticket data, IPHC catch data, IPHC tagging studies, NMML sea lion data, regulatory data, sea surface temperature, bathymetry data, coastline data.

metadata.title: Mariculture Permit Tracking
metadata.description: Data Type: Fish  ; The database tracks the status of mariculture permit applications in the department's permitting process, maintaining information on all mariculture ventures in the state. The GIS is a locational device derived as a visual by-product of the mariculture permit application and tracking process. Mariculture tracking is a joint project of the ADF&G and Department of Natural Resources.

metadata.title: Recreational Fisheries and Biology
metadata.description: Data Type: Fish  ; Data on catch, harvest, and participation in Alaska's recreational fisheries and the abundance, composition, dynamics, growth, and productivity of the associated fish populations. This data has been collected and analyzed for numerous projects and hundreds of reports. Data is divided by geographic extent and specific fisheries and populations. Data is scaled to specific lake, stream, saltwater site or subsites.

metadata.title: Stocking Records - State Hatcheries
metadata.description: Data Type: Fish  ; This historical database records the numbers of fish stocked in any location around the state supplementing the sport and commercial fisheries. Data covers 1966 to the present although the older data tends to be less reliable. Information is included for all species which FRED stocks and is limited to only those stockings by hatcheries owned by the state. This database ties into the Coded Wire Tag Database of the ADF&G Commercial Management and Development Division.

metadata.title: Glaciers
metadata.description: Data Type: Freshwater Systems;  Statewide glaciers were assembled from seventeen files in the USGS 1:2,000,000 Digital Line Graphs (DLG) dataset by using reselect on the MIN attribute. Although none of the DLG line attributes are maintained within the glaciers coverage, the following MIN values were used during the reselect process: 4060 (glacier length <4 km), 4061 (glacier length 4≤10 km), 4062 (glacier length 10≤17 km), 4063 (glacier length 17≤25 km), 4064 (glacier length 25≤37 km), 4065 (glacier length 37≤50 km), and 4066 (glacier length 50+ km).
metadata.notes:
Purpose: Unknown

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: Unknown

Access constraints: Requestor must complete GIS Starter Kit Data Agreement stating Terms and Conditions for use of Starter Kit Data.

Use constraints: DNR does not recommend use of this data at a larger scale. Greater detail for each layer is provided from DNR, Land Records Information Section, for each data module upon receipt of order.

metadata.title: Eastern Bering Sea Juvenile Salmon Surveys (By Ed Farley: AFSC Quarterly Report: Jul. - Sep. 2002)
metadata.description: During the eastern Bering Sea survey, conducted in Bristol Bay from 18 August to 14 September, 75 trawl stations were sampled beginning at the northern end of the  long. 161EW transect and ending on the southern end of the long. 166EW transect. During the northeastern Bering Sea survey (15 September to 12 October), 77 trawl stations across the shelf were sampled beginning at 58EN near Nunivak Island and ending north of St. Lawrence Island at 65EN .
metadata.notes:
Purpose: The primary goal of this annual surveys is to establish and verify the linkages between adult sockeye salmon survival and annual variations in biological characteristics of juvenile salmon.

Status: In Progress
